newsitem.title: USA: US Midwest direct hogs seen steady-off $0.50-trade.
newsitem.headline: US Midwest direct hogs seen steady-off $0.50-trade.

text.p: U.S. Midwest direct cash hog prices Wednesday were seen steady to $0.50 per cwt lower, pressured by Tuesday's large interior Iowa/southern Minnesota hog receipts on Tuesday, livestock dealers said.
Outlooks for active marketings again Wednesday also generated projections for weak cash hog prices, they said.
Tuesday's estimated interior Iowa/southern Minnesota hog run was estimated at 110,000 head. On Monday marketings totaled 79,000 which was below 100,000 estimate, USDA said.
Some producers waited until Tuesday to sell hogs on news that some packers were to be closed Monday.
Those closures were in observance of the Easter holiday, sources said.
Top hog prices at interior Iowa/southern Minnesota plants on Wednesday were seen ranging from $51.00 to $51.50, sources there said. Illinois top prices at the plant were expected at $50.50 to $51.00.

Indiana/Ohio top prices at plants were expected to range from $50.50 to $51.00. Most hogs Tuesday at Indiana and Ohio plants sold at a top of $51.50, although there were a few at $52.50 as one packer paid a premium for top quality animals.
Pork prices at midday were not well established, USDA said. Hams weighing 20-26 lbs were quoted $1.00-$2.00 per cwt lower and pork bellies $2.00 higher, USDA reported.
